It accuses the attorney general 's office of failing to comply with the 2002 law regarding smart guns , the name given to guns that contain technology that only allows them to be fired by their owner .
Under the law , three years after smart guns became available anywhere in the country , all guns sold in New Jersey would have to use the technology .
The lawsuit claims the attorney general has n't reported to the governor and legislature every six months on the availability of smart guns , as required by law .
